div.p: Mr Hale came as an agent to solicit a contribution for a private establishment for the support and disposal of poor orphan children— It was devised and is maintained by Misses A. and E. C. Fellows in Boston, who publish a quarto periodical journal, styled the Social Monitor and Orphan’s Advocate in Monthly numbers, one of which Mr Hale left with me. He says he was himself an orphan, supported and educated by these persons. Their plan is to withdraw from the poor houses of the country towns such orphan poor as they can find opportunity to provide for by placing them in families where care is taken to educate and maintain them— This is the day of the Anniversary celebration at Hingham— This day the Steam ship Caledonia Captain Lott, arrived at Boston from Liverpool and Halifax in 12 1/2 days with 92 passengers. And the Steamship Hibernia Captain Ryrie, sailed from Boston for Halifax and Liverpool— One calendar month now suffices for writing to London and receiving an answer— I finished reading Macaulay’s Article on Bacon, which I have read with pleasure, but which has kindled my thirst to see and compare Montagu’s edition of his works with that of Mallet which I possess.— and particularly to read Montagu’s life of the compound of Angel and Fiend Francis Bacon— Macaulay judges him with a mixture of excessive rigour and of extreme admiration and kindness. There is a natural alliance between admiration and love—and a natural affinity between contempt and hatred— But between admiration and hatred there is none; and between Love and contempt there may be an easy transition but no union. Macaulay’s estimate of Bacon’s philosophical system and discoveries appear to me to be greatly exaggerated, and his condemnation of the Grecian Philosophy much too broad and universal.— The Stoic, Epicurean, and Platonic philosophies were as full of practical good as the novum organum. When Pythagoras sacrificed a hecatomb, for having discovered the relative measure of the right angle and the hypothenuse, it was not the mathematical abstraction that caused his joy.— When Archimedes said to Hiero give me a stand I will move the earth, it was not a barren problem of mechanics of which he boasted. The sayings of the wise men—the golden verses—the inductive reasoning of Socrates were all eminently practical and useful— Bacon proposed a new method of study, and disparaged too much that which preceded him. While I have been reading Macaulay Bacon himself slumbers. I have fallen into idle habits— I rise about 4. Wash, scrub and curry one hour—read first permanent matter—then Newspapers and pamphlets which come by Mail— Journalize 3 hours—searching for papers at intervals till 2. dine. Afternoon Siesta two hours— Yawn, and range about the house and garden till Sunset— Tea— Evening with my family.

My Son with Alexander S. Johnson, and Charles’s sons John and Charles went this morning on a fishing party to Cohasset— They returned before dinner and I dined with Mr Johnson at Charles’s— I wrote to Mrs Harriet Boyd at Green Bay, Wiskonsin Territory, authorising her with her husband to draw upon me for 80. dollars payable at one day’s sight at the Merchant’s Bank Boston—being for her portion of the balance of the proceeds of sale of Mr T. B. Johnson’s effects directed by the judge of the orphan’s Court at Washington to be distributed between his sisters.— I answered also the invitation of Mr B. R. Curtis to attend at the Meeting of the Alumni of Harvard University the day before Commencement, and to preside at their dinner— I declined though with a very strong inclination to accept— And I wrote to Mr George Fuller, Administrator of the Estate of Moses Gill; requesting him to transfer to the Executors of the Will and Trustees of Ward Nicholas Boylston, seven shares of the stock of the Pennsylvania Bank of the United States, of the 25 which I transferred to him last April. A great part of this day was absorbed in looking up loose pamphlet documents of which I have immense multitudes in such disorder and confusion that whenever I want any one of them it is like seeking one grain of wheat in a bushel of chaff—a desolating search three times out of four terminating in disappointments, and loss of the time.— With the design of answering Mr William Wallace Whitney’s Letter, I recurred to my Address to my Constituents at Braintree on the 17th of September 1842— I soon found the passage containing the statements and opinions which Mr Whitney requests me to reconsider— It was the charge that in 1836. President Jackson expressly authorised General Gaines to invade the Mexican territory—and take post at Nacogdoches which he did.— I find throughout the whole passage no charge against General Gaines, but I did not state in my address, the equivocating disavowal by Jackson in Secretary Forsyth’s Letter to the Mexican Minister Gorostiza of 10. May 1836. of Gaines’s actual occupation of Nacogdoches. Of that disavowal Mr Whitney takes no notice in his Letter to Bryant Editor of the New-York Evening Post—a disingenuous omission which must not be suffered to pass without exposure— But for that purpose I must review the whole series of transactions of that period, and especially the whole controversy respecting the Gorostiza pamphlet— In this pursuit I passed from my Address at Braintree, to my fragment speech of June and July 1838. where I charged upon Jackson’s administration these escroceries of his conduct towards Mexico, and once engaged in the reperusal of that Speech the leisure of the day was consumed— Mr Lunt was here this afternoon— And Walter Hellen arrived from Washington.

I went to Boston this morning, with Mrs Charles Adams Alexander S. Johnson and my Grand-daughter Mary-Louisa— Charles went with his son John in his own Curricle. Mrs Charles and Mary-Louisa alighted at Miss Wainwright’s door— I went first to the Emancipator and Morning Chronicle Office, where I found the Revd. Joshua Leavitt. I delivered to him the manuscript copies of the proceedings in the District and Circuit Courts of the United States in Georgia upon the case of the Antelope.— I had received a Letter from Mr Charles T. Torrey in jail at Baltimore, requesting the loan of these papers for the use of his counsel. Mr Leavitt promised to have them forwarded. I then went to Charles’s Office and thence to the bottom of commercial wharf on board of the new ship John Quincy Adams, just built for Mr. Daniel P. Parker who has given to it this name— Built at Medford—of 650 tons burden already nearly loden with a cargo of cotton fabrics and bound to Canton in China. She has a sculptured figure head likeness of me, larger than life of about 8 feet in stature, and considered as a strong resemblance, with the name and the family arms carved upon the stern— Mr Parker had assembled a few of his friends and mine to meet me there; and after taking me all over the ship and introducing to me the master workmen, ship carpenters, block-makers riggers and caulkers, and especially the carver of the head and stern Mr Mason, had a temperance collation of cakes, grapes apricots and limonade served up in the cabin, where Coll. Josiah Quincy, introduced by a short sentiment complimentary a toast so flattering that I could not fix it in my Memory. I was so overwhelmed with humiliation that I had not the power of articulation left and only muttered a few incoherent words, and hid my head for shame! Coll. Quincy relieved the dulness of the Scene by his usual smartness of wit, and he called on the Sailor’s preacher the Revd Mr Taylor, who made a short and amusing Speech— Mr Abbot Lawrence and Mr Gould joined in the conversation, and a number of Ladies cheered the company with their smiles.— About half past 12. I took my leave and the company dispersed I gave a parting blessing of silent prayer for the destiny of the ship and returned through Faneuil Hall Market to Charles’s Office.— Saw there Dr. George Parkman and Mr Andrews the broker— Thence we rendez vous’d with Mrs Charles and Mary-Louisa at Dr Frothingham’s, and returned home to Quincy to dine After dinner I was disqualified for writing— Elizabeth De Windt, now Mr Christopher Pierce Cranch came this afternoon to spend some days with us. She was married last winter and has since resided in the City of New-York— She is in feeble and infirm health.

Communion day. Mr Lunt’s morning text was from 1. Peter 3. [“]For Christ also hath once suffered for sins, the just for the unjust, that he might bring us to God, being put to death in the flesh, but quickened by the Spirit: 19 by which also he went and preached unto the spirits in prison.” It was a discourse preparatory to the administration of the communion— The verse immediately preceding the text says “For, it is better, if the will of God be so, that ye suffer for well-doing than for evil-doing.” an admirable principle of morals, and well deserving to be itself the text of a whole sermon— Mr Lunt said that the Apostle Peter must have had an acute sense of the difference between these two modes of suffering— He had suffered for evil-doing, when he forsook his lord and Master in the last scene of his life; and he was to suffer for well-doing, when he died a martyr to the Christian cause— There is something obscure, and which seems to require explanation in the assertion that Christ after his crucifixion went and preached unto the Spirits in prison— The main argument of the epistle is an earnest exhortation to all the disciples of Christ to follow his example by suffering, not only without swerving from the path of righteousness, but by persevering in that of active beneficence. In the administration of the Communion an affecting incident occurred by the appearances of the two new Deacons to distribute the bread and wine in the place of the two who for several years past had performed that service—Savil and William Spear— After the Meeting I began to walk home, but was overtaken by a sudden shower of which the water fell in a flood, and I was driven to take refuge in the carriage which was taking home Louisa Smith and Mrs Charles. Even that barely saved me from a drenching.— Mr Bigelow handed me as we were coming out of the Temple a very urgent invitation from Jonathan Chapman Chairman of the Whig State central Committee, to attend and preside at a Mass Convention of the Whigs of Massachusetts upon Boston Common, on Thursday the 19th. of September next, and said he would call on me for an answer this evening— I attended meeting this afternoon alone— Mr Lunts text was from 2. Corinthians 7.1. the last line of the verse—“perfecting holiness in the fear of God.” The doctrine of the discourse was that the fear of God, that is Religion is the exclusive and only foundation of perfect virtue; a principle which I hold to be certain though perfect virtue does not always follow from religious faith. This Sermon was well written, well reasoned, and well delivered. I preferred it to the one of the morning. The fear of God is the sum total of the Old Testament— The immortality of the Soul is the vital essence of the New— From these two articles of faith necessarily follows the responsibility of Man, the only guarantee of human virtue. Mr and Mrs G. T. Bigelow and Mrs John Angier visited us this Evening. Mr Bigelow undertook to deliver my verbal answer to Mr Chapman’s invitation declining to preside at the Mass Meeting of whigs on Boston Common— Age and infirmity admit of no composition— Mrs Elizabeth Cranch was so unwell that she could not come down to dinner— But she revived in the Evening.

Alexander Smith Johnson eldest surviving son, of my deceased niece, youngest daughter of my brother Charles, after spending a week with us, left us this morning, to return to the city of New-York, where he resides, and is a practising lawyer— He was born 30 July 1817. at Utica, and was educated at Yale College (See my diary of 1. June 1830. Vol. 10. p. 466.) The Revd Dr Storrs of Braintree paid us a morning visit with his wife and sister— I called at the Quincy stone bank, and deposited there 20 Eagles and 20 half Eagles which I had received at the Bank of the Metropolis at Washington—reflecting that a deposit there of gold coin, is far safer than in my own house. After dinner, Mr George Warren, a member of the Boston Mercantile Library Association came and urgently invited me, to deliver the introductory Lecture to the course which they propose to commence next October— I had hoped to be spared the annoyance of these applications by my card in the National Intelligencer ofJuly last, but they are more numerous than ever. I told Mr Warren that I could make no engagement, but would deliver a Lecture if I should find it in my power— Mr Loring of Hingham and his wife were also here—and I promised to go with him to a fishing party at Cohasset, on Thursday of next week— Three times this afternoon I sat down to continue writing my proposed address to my Constituents—and wrote not more than five lines— Read not a single concerted or solitary experiment of Bacon’s Natural History, nor one page of Macaulay’s Miscellaneous articles from the Edinburgh Review— Great part of the day was consumed in overhauling my pamplets putting them into confusion worse confounded, and hunting up 25 of my own composition of which I made a parcel and gave it to Alexander S. Johnson— I made out last summer a list of 72 Miscellanies in print by me, which on looking over now I find very deficient.— In American State Papers collected by Lowrie and Clark and published by Gales and Seaton in 21 volumes folio, the first four contain the Documents relating to foreign Affairs, and of these there are in the fourth volume many written by me— My hand is in almost every collection of the Session of Congress documents from year to year for the last 30 years, and not unfrequently before— I rise so early that in reading or writing I find myself oppressed by drowsiness, and compelled to quit my table for more stirring occupation— I then begin to ransack my old papers, which wakes me up, but consumes my time, and dissipates my thoughts. I have also resorted to the practice of taking a Siesta after dinner which makes up for the shortness of my sleeping hours at Night. But it is a subtle thief of Life.

I am so far relieved from my lameness that I can walk without spraining my leg— I went up the hill and saw the Sun rise from the East corner of Charles’s house—not quite clear, but so that I could mark the first beam of his appearance above the horizon.— I filled earthen pot N. 3. with earth and planted in it 3. Washington red plumstones; as I had done in each of the other two— I took other morning exercise of an hour, my health recreation and apology for wasted time— There are four stocks, budded last Summer by E Price Greenleaf, 3 apple and one Pear, which have put forth shoots, the pear 3 feet 9 inches—the apple in front of my study window 2. feet—that in Fanny’s plat 28 inches—that in Mary Louisa’s plat 21 inches— The stalks of all the apples stunted by the congregaiton of green aphides and black ants. There are seven shag-bark walnuts up in the bed behind the tool box up, from my last fall’s plantation— I would gladly save them from the frosts of next winter, but know not how. Mr Lunt called, having already returned the 2d. volum of my miscellanies which I have given to my grand daughter Mary Louisa— He told me he had been pleased with my essay on the character of Desdemona, but did not concur with my opinion of her— I asked him on what point he differed.— He said on the point that the colour of Othello constitutes the Tragedy, and on my rigorous estimate of the character of Desdemona— But he was not disposed to discuss, and I did not press for it— He said there was a man at work in the graveyard engraving on the ministerial monument the name of Mrs. Anna Fiske second wife of the Revd. Moses Fiske, and before that, widow of Daniel Quincy, and mother of John Quincy whose name I bear— She was my great-great-grand-mother—my trisayenle, and I revere her memory as if she were mother. That she was buried in this Tomb, is ascertained by an extract from Fairfields Journal quoted in Mr Lunt’s two centennial Discourses— Mr Lunt had a list of my published miscellanies, which he gave me, requesting me to revise and correct it— This has stimulated me to re-examine the immense mass of my pamphlets and old Congressional documents which appals me as I proceed. Walter Hellen offers to assist me and this day we made some progress, but a whole month will not suffice for the task. I this day found at last the collections which I had made last Summer, and preceding Seasons, of my own miscellanies, to give to my son, and others of my relatives and friends— That for my Son contains a number sufficient to make four large volumes for binding—and there are scattered about in newspapers and other public journals an ample number to make up four volumes more; besides manuscripts numberless. I received this day Letters from William H. Seward and Christopher Morgan of Auburn, New-York, inviting me to write for publication a Letter on the subject of the annexation of Texas to the Union; and an invitation from George Bliss, George Dwight and Henryinviting me to a whig mass Convention at Springfield on the 9th.

I saw the Sun this day, rise, and set, from my Son’s house; neither entirely clear; but both enough so to mark the moment of his emerging and disappearance. Mr Enos White of Weymouth came this morning to solicit a contribution for surrounding with a fence, and putting into some order the grave yard of the parish of which my grandfather William Smith was many years the Pastor— There he, and his wife Elizabeth Quincy, my Grandmother and Dr Cotton Tufts, and his wife Lucy Quincy, my Grandmother’s sister, and their son Cotton, all lie buried— In that spot in October 1775. I attended the funeral of my Grandmother.— And there on the 6th. of May 1833 I attended the funeral of Cotton Tufts the son. I told Mr White that in the Summers of 1774 and 1775. I had lived several months in the house of my Grandfather at Weymouth, and he and his wife seemed to me, as a second father and mother. When last there I had seen the Stones over the graves of my grand parents, and would cheerfully contribute to a fencing round the enclosure, and other reparations for the protection of the place from insult— Mr Daniel Greenleaf paid a morning visit to me, and to Mrs Elizabeth Cranch now the wife of his nephew Christopher Pierce Cranch. Mr Greenleaf is 83 years of age, and so deaf, that it is difficult to hold a conversation with him—and Mrs Cranch is so infirm in health, that it is doubtful whether she will out live him.— She and Mary-Louisa dined this day at Mrs Adams’s my brother Thomas’s widow.— My wife received a Letter from Mrs Treadway at Richmond— Her daughter Mrs Crane has lost the fine boy whom she had with her when they visited us in August 1842. I received this day a Letter from Rufus King and 4 others of the State, Clay Central Committee at Albany, New-York, inviting and urging me to write for publication a Letter upon Texas— The Letter received yesterday from W. H. Seward and Morgan, was in aid of this request. Also a Letter from M. M. Fisher of Medway, requesting in behalf of the District and County Committee of the Liberty party of the Eighth Congregational Distric of Massachusetts, a conference with me next Monday, in relation to the nomination of a Candidate to represent the District in the 29th. Congress— And a Letter from George Fuller, administrator de bonis non, with the will annexed of Lieutt. Governor Moses Gill, respecting the 7 Bank shares which I transferred to him by mistake. I wrote on the back of the Deed of the Congregational Society of the Town of Quincy by their Treasurer George W. Beale, to me, of Pew N. 6 in the Stone Temple, an assignment of all my right, title and Estate therein to Benjamin R. Curtis, his heirs and Assigns— Much of the day wasted in ransacking the farm house for old documents and pamphlets.

My Son, went to Boston, with his youngest Son, Arthur to consult Dr. Bigelow. His wife and my granddaughter Mary Louisa went with him. They returned home to dine, and Charles brought out the 61st. volume of Niles’s Register, containing page 219. Clement C. Clay’s Letter to the Legislature of the State of Alabama of 12. Novr. 1841. resigning his seat in the Senate of the United States—in which he recommends emphatically the political doctrine of Thomas Jefferson, that the Northern Democracy are the natural allies of the Slaveholders of the South— I have long been desirous of referring to the Letter of Mr Jefferson in which this principle was avowed; an also to an Article in the North-American Review, by Edward Everett commenting upon it— Charles brought out the 4th. Volume of Jefferson’s writings, and the 22d volume of the North American Review where I expected to find these Articles. In my searches this day with Walter Hellen for old documents and pamphlets at the farm-house I found the anonymous pamphlet published by John Forsyth Secretary of State in 1837. entitled “Examination and Review of a pamphlet, printed and secretly circulated by M. E. Gorostiza, late Envoy Extraordinary from Mexico; previous to his departure from the United States; and by him entitled ‘Correspondence between the Legation Extraordinary of Mexico, and the Department of State of the United States, respecting the passage of the Sabine, by the Troops under the command of General Gaines[’”]— I had alread found, a loose copy of the Message of President Van Buren to H.R.U.S. of 26. Feby 1838; containing a copy and translation of Gorostiza’s pamphlet; in answer to a Resolution offered by me, and adopted by the House on the 20th. of February 1838— These two pamphets are indispensably necessary to me, for the preparation of my answer to Mr Whitney. Also the Session Message of 24. Congress 2d. Session 6. December 1836. wherein President Jackson disavows the entry by General Gaines upon the Mexican Territory. Also Messages of 27. April and 4 July 1838. N. 351. 25 Congress 2. Session—especially from p. 765 of the latter.— At page 766. there is a Letter from Genl. Macomb to Gaines of 26. January 1836.—enclosing a Letter of Instructions from the Secretary of War dated 23. January 1836— These were the precise orders upon which Gaines crossed the Sabine and took Post at Nacogdoches—but the Instructions themselves are not there They were communicated to the House in the Message of 14 May 1836. 24. Congress 1. Session. N. 256. in answer to a Resolution of the House of 10. May 1836 on a motion of Edward Everett the day before. The instructions are obscurely worded, and do not give explicit authority to cross the line— That however is given by Letter from the Secretary of War of 25. April 1836. five days after the conference between Forsyth and Gorostiza, when the Mexican Minister was apprized of the intention of Jackson to authorize the invasion of Mexico by Gaines.

I awake now habitually before the Clock in our entry strikes 3. and cannot sleep again— I lay an hour more or less and rise with the first glimpse of twilight. At this when the sky is clear, I see every night just before going to bed between 10. and 11. the planet Jupiter rise in the North east, about the extremest Northern declination of the Sun; and at half past 3. in the morning. Venus rises nearly at the same point— It seems as if it were the same star night and morning; fixed in the heavens, with unceasing and unfading splendor. I suppose that not one person in a thousand would understand me should I say that this incident has given and continues to give me a transient sensation of pleasure. I resumed the practice of allowing two hours of morning exercise, devoted to my seedling trees. I planted two Washington plum stones in a plat in the Seminary, next the Barn fence, and covered them with an inverted earthen flower pot, bottom broken off. The summer house cellar was choked up with weeds, from 3. to 5. feet high. I plucked and hoed them up; and disclosed 2 seedling shagbark trees, up from last years nuts of the old adjoining tree— Mr G. W. Beale called here, and I acknowledged before him as a Justice of Peace, the Assignment to Benjamin R. Curtis of pew N. 6, in the Stone Temple— Mrs John Adams, and Mrs Cranch, dined at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— Mr and Mrs Erastus Brooks, (Margaret Cranch) and Mrs Lucy Dawes were here this afternoon— Charles and his wife and daughter, this Evening.— This day the Railway from New-York to Boston, by the way of Long Island was first opened, and I note from the Atlas Newspaper the time within which the journey was performed.
Time from Brooklyn South Ferry to Boston, per Passenger Train over the Long-Island Rail-road. Friday 9. August 1844.
