My morning exercise encroaches already upon my hours for labour, and the search for old documents and pamphlets absorbs time beyond all computation— I worked this morning upon an old Apple tree in the alley between my own and Charles’s house, and which bears Russetton Apples I propose to strip off its parasite ulcers, and loosen the ground about its roots— Mrs Elizabeth (De Windt) Cranch who has been spending a week with us, left us, to go and pass another with Mrs John Angier at Medford, and then return to her father’s house at Cedar grove, Fishkill Landing, on Hudson river— Mary and her daughter Mary Louisa went with her to Boston and returned home to dine— Charles A. Cummings, heretofore a School-teacher, and in 1840 Selectman of Quincy, a fierce democrat called on me this morning with a Revd Mr Goodrich a Minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church to solicit a subscription for building a new church of that denomination in this town— There is already a church of the same denomination near Quincy point— Mr Goodrich belongs to the Providence Conference, and the town of Quincy falls within that jurisdiction. Mr Goodrich was appointed by the Conference to preach here, but the proprietor, of the church or of the pews refused to receive him, and will not permit him to occupy the Church. And so Mr Cummings gets up a contribution to build another— I declined on the ground that this was a family quarrel, with which Strangers should not interfere, but which the parties should settle by amicable consultation, or by appeal to the Laws of the Land.— They said they supposed that the right of possession of the Church must ultimately be decided by a suit at Law, and they would have to commence an action— But that would necessarily consume a year, and perhaps two before the final decision, and in the mean time, they had no place where they could perform their devotions— I persevered in declining the contribution A man by the name of Horatio Green, an itinerant Cabinet maker traveling about the Country in search of work came to see me for the mere sake of curiosity, because he makes it a practice to go and see all the great men whenever they fall in his way.— He made some slight apology for intrusion, but gave me to understand that he considered it a clear right for any labourer to visit all the great men, and talk politics with them ad libitum.— He entered accordingly, upon the Tariff and the Bank and Texas and Tyler, the burden of all which was that the whole burden of taxation ought to be brought to bear, upon the wealthy; and that the labourer ought to have light work and heavy wages.— This is genuine democracy, and the universal feeling of the masses— The rest of the day was swallowed up in unpacking the three chests of books and papers which came round by Sea from Washington, and in which with a fresh multitude of documents to assort, I miss two or three articles indispensable to complete sets.

Mr Young, pastor of the New South Church Boston, exchanged this day with Mr Lunt, and preached this morning from Psalm 4:6. “There be many that say, who will shew us any good?”— He observed that it was considered as evidence of a discontented and complaining spirit in those who were apt to indulge themselves with this question— As if they felt the gift of life as a burden, and not a blessing. Mr Young took only this clause of the verse for his text— The first Sermon of Sterne published under the name of Yorick, is on this subject; but he adds to the text the latter clause of the verse— “Lord, lift thou up the light of thy countenance upon us.”— Sterne begins by a general assertion of a propensity in mankind to search for happiness—which position he diversifies, by reference to the modifications of the pursuit, by men in the several conditions of life— Mr Young dwelt on the unreasonableness and ingratitude of repining at the allotments of life, and enumerated the sources of enjoyment common to all men— He argued much on the theory of the optimist school, and insisted that many of the incidents which are dreaded as evils turn out to be blessings in disguise— Sterne’s argument is that all the usual pursuits of happiness terminate in disappointment— Both come to the same conclusion, that the real good, the consummate enjoyment of human life can be found only in religion.— The second part of the verse, omitted by Mr Young, but included in Sterne’s text is exceedingly appropriate to that argument. Mr Young came home with me, and dined with us. I mentioned Sterne’s sermon to him; but he did not seem to be acquainted with it. He did not howeve say that he had never seen it— His text in the afternoon was Proverbs 13.11. “Wealth gotten by vanity shall be diminished: but he that gathereth by labour shall increase.” This is an aphorism of private morality, not in the form of a precept but a statement of cause and effect—invariable as the laws of physical Nature. three thousand years ago, the experience of mankind had proved uniformly so, and Solomon made a proverb of it— Wealth gotten by Vanity— The words Vanity—and diminished, are to be noted for their significancy— The French Genevan translation, instead of Vanity, uses Fraud— Charles Thomson has “injustice.”— The term Vanity is more comprehensive and includes wealth acquired suddenly—by chance, by gaming—by any other mode than laborious Industry; and the experience of mankind still after the lapse of thirty centuries witnesses the same results. Mr Young visited with severity the propensity of young American women to form matrimonial connections with foreigners, especially if they have the title of Count, which he said was as common in some parts of Europe, as that of Esquire, or Captain here— At Charles’s house to see the Sun set, I met there Mr and Mrs George T. Bigelow— Something said of the mass Meeting of 10 or 15000 whigs at Springfield last Friday; where Robert C. Winthrop, Rufus Choate and Daniel Webster made Speeches.
Sun rose 5.3. Set 7.7. both crystal clear.

Rose behind the barn on the summit of the distant hill Set behind the peak of the sloping Northwestern hill that bounds the horizon. Rising at 4. I gave precisely two hours to bodily exercise, my seedlings and the old apple-tree in the lane— I expected the visit of Mr M. M. Fisher and the deputation from the Liberty party Committee but they did not come— The Revd. Peter Sanborn, and Mr. Moses Welsh of Reading, Middlesex County paid me a morning visit. Mr Sanborn said he was a Minister of the word of God, and preached yesterday for Mr Perkins at Braintree— He was making an excursion for his health and amusement, and accompanied his friend Mr Welsh who came to visit some of his Relations at Weymouth. He was a few months older than me.— He had a great veneration for all the Patriots of our Revolution, and La Fayette had shaken him most cordially by the hand. He was much inclined to talk politics—said he was of the Liberty party—asked me, if Mr Clay was really the cause of the Cilley duel—and whether he should vote for Mr Birney.— I told him that I could say nothing about Mr Clay’s concern in the Cilley, or any other duel, but that I was very sorry he had ever taken part in any one: and that if he should vote for Birney, his vote would count for Polk.— His friend Welsh very earnestly desired him to remember that— I called at the Office of the Quincy Patriot to enquire if Mr Green had a copy or two left of the pamphlet edition of my Letter of 4 July 1843. to the Anti Slavery Committee at Bangor; but Green was not there, and his journeyman had been only a short time at the Office and knew nothing about it— Then I looked in at the Office of the Quincy Aurora, to enquire if Mr Clapp proposed to publish an account of the celebration at Hingham on the 2d. of this month. He said he had my Letter to Miss Anna Quincy Thaxter already in type for next Thursday— Mrs De Windt has published another book called Melzinga A Souvenir by C. A. D. 1845. consisting of what is called a Journal, a sort of mystical narrative of incidents of daily occurrence dated from time to time in measured lines of unequal length, with and without rhyme, half verse half prose Then sundry miscellaneous fugitive pieces original and selected, among which are my lines upon Retrospection written in September 1840. and which I thought were irretrievably lost— My Letter to her of 31. Octr. 1841. with the tale of Charles the fifths Clocks, and my Sonnet to the Sun-dial—this last somewhat mutilated by misprints. I resumed the daily reading of a few pages of Bacon’s Sylva-Sylvarum, or a natural history in ten centuries— I have read the first century, or one hundred experiments upon percolation— It reads like a Cookery Book, or a compilation of recipes, or quack medicines. It is hard to read, and must be taken in broken doses. I strongly suspect that the results of Many of the experiments are fallacious. Mrs T. B. Adams and two Misses Harrod took tea and spent the Evening here— Mary was taken unwell last Friday; and this day took to her chamber and bed— Dr Woodward here.

Last night just before going to bed, returning in the dark to the house, ascending the rough hewn stone steps of the eastern back-door, I lost my balance and fell backwards, stricking the ground just below the right knee, and spraining the cord of the leg.— A repetition of the Jersey-city disaster—though of a milder type— I bathed the part where the skin was broken with vinegar and pasted over it a piece of brown paper steeped in vinegar, tied round with my cravat to keep it on overnight— This morning the paper stuck to the wounded spot like court-plaister— I took off the cravat, and left the paper adhesive. I medicated my old Apple-tree; and hoed up and manured my Nursery seedling plats to the end of my two hours, but felt the sprain of my right leg as a warning to suspend for a time that part of my labours— Miss Samson the Seamstress has been here working for the ladies since yesterday morning. Mary had been quite ill since last Friday, but had said nothing of it, nor taking any advice till yesterday after breakfast, when able to sustain herself no longer Dr. Woodward was sent for and ordered her to keep her bed. Two Gentlemen, whigs,

from Lancaster Pennsylvania visited me for curiosity sake and talked of course politics and about the Presidential Election In the midst of a heated canvas Henry A. Muhlenberg the democratic Polk and Dallas candidate for the Office of Governor of Pennsylvania died suddenly of apoplexy, some ten days since— Mr Locher says that the democratic nomination in place of Muhlenberg, will be Mr Shunk, a stronger man, and more likely to succeed than Muhlenberg. Henry Hardwick came and wants to purchase about an Acre and a quarter of my land adjoining his— He has coveted it many years but has never measured it to let me know what he wants nor made me a specific offer for it— I told him he must do both, and he said he would— Mr Peter C. Brooks came out from Medford with his Niece Miss Phillips to spend a couple of days with his daughter— Walter Hellen and I dined with him at Charles’s house; and we sat two full hours after dinner, retracing the steps of time, and calling up the shadows of departed years— We took a walk towards Sunset, around Charles’s hill, and looked at the Boston State-house, the Bunker hill column Boston Harbour, and the cap of the State-house at its mouth— Evening at home— I found the Volume of the Journal of U.S. House of Representatives for 1822, and what I wanted in it; but not time to write it out. I am reading the second century of Lord Bacon’s Sylva Sylvarum, which is upon Music— Curious experiments— But if this work, the Nine Books de Augmentis Scientiarum and the Novum Organum are all component parts of the Instauratio magna they form a strangely constructed book— Dr. Rowley’s preface first purports to be published in Bacon’s life time, and concludes after his death.

I rose this morning at four O’Clock with a head-ache, after an hour and a half of sleepless repose since I awoke. The habitual state of mind abridges my slumbers— I perceived that I must renounce the project of going to the fishing party to Cohasset to-morrow—and wrote a note to Mr Loring advising him of this disability. I sent the note before six O’Clock this morning to the Post-Office, to go by the morning Stage to Hingham— Mr French, sent me back word that the Stage was gone but that he would send my Letter this morning to Mr Loring. Dr Woodward was here to Mrs John Adams whose complaint continues unabated.— I received a Letter from Jacob Tuck corresponding Secretary of the Total abstinence Society at Cohasset, informing me that there would be a great Temperance gathering there to morrow; and that the Committee of Arrangements, having heard that I should be at Cohasset were anxious that I should be present if I could find it convenient any part of the day.— I supposed my note to Mr Loring would serve for an answer to Mr Tuck— Mr Brooks called to see me. We had hoped to have him to dine with us this day, but the illness of Mrs John Adams disappointed us.— Before dinner Mr Brooks, my Son and myself rode to the stone quarries and saw three of the four fluted pilasters, with their caps of the Ionic Order in preparation for the town Hall which they are building opposite the Stone Temple— The fourth of the pilasters was at the hall about to be raised— One of the workmen said it took sixty days to flute one of the pilasters. They are 20 feet long.— We were obliged to hasten home, which we reached just in time to escape a heavy shower of rain— I found the sinews of my right leg so much strained that I walked with difficulty and pain. Walter Hellen and I dined again at my Son’s with Mr Brooks and Miss Phillips. After dinner Mr William Minot, and Isaac P. Davis came out from Boston; and finding I was not at home, joined us at Charles’s, where they took tea and returned to Boston— I spent the evening with Mr Brooks at my Son’s— Mr Minot spoke of a Speech of Thomas H. Benton at Boonville, published in the National Intelligencer of last Monday—his last blast against the annexation Treaty— And I. P. Davis told me that Tyler’s Madisonian had a violent attack upon me for my Letter to Miss Anna Quincy Thaxter, which it calls a Letter to Miss Anna Thayer— Webster and Winthrop at Springfield, took the proper tone for treating the Texas plot— I wrote the Letter to Miss Thaxter expressly to raise a blister— It is becoming public—but has been printed only in the Atlas of all the Boston Newspapers My time is yet most distressingly absorbed— I finished reading the second and began the third century of Bacon’s Sylva Sylvarum.— The two Books consist of experiments upon music and the motions of Sounds— It is more than half a century since I first read Bacon’s Essays— Would that I had then read three times over all his works. I might then have derived great benefit from them; for the Essays were not barren. But now—all reading to me is percolation—or Sound.

My rustic labours, and my sallying forth to see the Sun-rise are indefinitely postponed by the disability of my crippled limbs. Mr Peter C. Brooks, and his Niece Miss Phillips returned home to Medford this morning, and my Son went into Boston, with his Son John Quincy to have him entered as a scholar at the Latin town School, which he did after a sharp examination— The term of study, is of five years, of preparation to enter the University.— May I implore a blessing upon this event—and for this boy? How much of Hope and how much of Fear mingles in every glance at the future— The Soul must rely upon him whose tender mercies are over all his works— Shortly after breakfast Mr Loring came in from Hingham to enquire what had become of me. He had not received the note which I had sent yesterday morning with entire confidence that he would receive it before Noon. After waiting for me this morning nearly two hours, he came to see if some disaster had befallen me— I told him of my second accident and regretted his disappointment and my own. He urged me to come over to the dinner, or to the evening tea-party; but I thought it most prudent to decline.— Towards evening, Dr Codman came in with his Son, returning from the Cohasset fishing party— The day he said had been fine, but the fishing not very successful— They had only caught about 50 haddock— No Cod.— Miss Susan Tufts paid us also an afternoon visit. She was of the Weymouth Committee appointed to confer with me about the fitting up of the parish cemetery. She had declined to come over with Mr Enos White, but she now came by herself, and intimated what she supposed was desired, and perhaps expected of me.— Mr and Mrs Grinnell of New Bedford also paid us a visit; returning from an excursion to Saratoga Springs which they left the day before yesterday morning.— I rode this afternoon with Louisa C. Smith, Mrs Charles and her youngest boy Arthur to Mount Wollaston, and to Germantown which I take a sober and chastised pleasure in visiting once at least every year— Finished reading the third Century of Bacon’s Sylva Sylvarum. “We have laboured, as may appear in this inquisition of sounds diligently: both because sound is one of the most hidden portions of nature, as we said in the beginning, and because it is a virtue which may be called incorporeal and immateriate: whereof there be in nature but few. Besides we were willing, now, in these our first centuries, to make a pattern or precedent, of an exact inquisition; and we shall do the like, hereafter, in some other subjects which require it. For we desire that men should learn, and perceive how severe a thing the true inquisition of nature is; and should accustom themselves by the light of particulars to enlarge their minds to the amplitude of the world, and not reduce the world to the narrowness of their minds.[”]
Bacon’s Sylva sylvarum— Century 3. Experiment 290. The key.

Mary still continues confined to her bed; and I am yet a cripple. My only excursion from our house to the porch of Charles’s to see the Sun set—but he went down in a thick cloud and disappointed me. But the day was fully occupied. I resumed the writing of an Address to my Constituents one daily page of which with one of Diary is all that I can accomplish— Charles brought me a bond to execute with him as his surety; to the judge of probate for the County of Suffolk, with a penalty of sixty thousand dollars, as trustee by the Will of Thomas B. Johnson for the annuities to his Sisters; which I signed, requesting Charles to furnish me, with a copy of it— I read the fourth century of Bacon’s experiments in consort and experiments solitary of the Sylva Sylvarum— This century is upon acceleration—and begins with Experiments in consort, touching the clarification of liquors and the accelerating thereof— “Acceleration of time, in works of Nature, may well be esteemed inter Magnalia naturae. And even in divine miracles, accelerating of the time is next to the creating of the matter”— This observation introduces the book one remarkable feature of which is that it accredits the Alchemist fable of transmuting metals into gold N 326. is an experiment solitary touching the making of gold— He says, “by occasion of handling the axioms touching maturation, we will direct a trial, touching the maturing of metals, and thereby turning some of them into gold; for we conceive indeed, that a perfect good concoction, or digestion, or maturation of some metals. will produce gold[”]— 328. is an experiment solitary touching the nature of gold.— “Gold hath these natures; greatness of weight; closeness of parts, fixation; pliantness or softness; immunity from rust, colour or tincture of yellow. Therefore the sure way, though most about to make gold, is to know the causes of the several natures before rehearsed, and the axioms concerning the same. For if a man can make a metal that hath all these properties, let men dispute whether it be gold or no?[”]— There is also in this book an Experiment solitary touching chameleons. 360— [“]They have a foolish tradition in magic, that if a chameleon be burnt upon the top of an house, it will raise a tempest: supposing, according to their vain dreams of sympathies, because he nourisheth with air, his body should have great virtue to make impression upon the air.” Was it worth while to record such experiments as that?— Again. 399. [“]The heat of the Sun maketh men black in some Countries, as in Æthiopia and Guiney &c. Fire doth it not, as we see in glass men that are continually about the fire”— And read the rest of this precious experiment. By way of relief, I read Macaulay’s Review of Croker’s Edition, of Boswell’s life of Johnson— Paradox mounted upon stilts. Boswell was the most contemptible of human beings, and his book is the best book that ever was published—but Mr Croker has spoiled it— The tree must no longer be judged by its fruit.

I ventured out this morning to see the Sunrise, and visit my seedling trees.— But the scraping of the skin under my knee was not healed, and in the course of the day became some what inflamed, and the leg swollen. A small plaister of diaculum salve applied this afternoon covered the wound and allayed the inflammation— Charles took his son John to Boston, for a visit to Mr Grinnell—at New-Bedford. The day was oppressively warm, and I sought refuge from dejection of spirits in reading Bacon’s fifth century of experiments, and Macaulay’s Review of Lord Nugent’s Memorials of John Hampden. My afternoon writing hours were absorbed by a visit from Mr Ellis of Dedham, laden with enquiries about the claims of Amasa Dunbar, and William Barron, of which I could give him but an indifferent account.— I recurred to the House Journal of the last Session, and found the case of Amasa Dunbar, first referred to the Committee of Revolutionary pensions, and then a report by Mr Rathbun, moving the discharge of the Committee from the further consideration of this and sundry other claims, and the papers laid on the table. Of the case of William Barron I could give him no account, but that the Committee had reported against it— I mark these cases in the margin to be remembered at the next Session, if my life and health are spared to be there. For the continuous remembrance of the course of private claims and petitions is among the most arduous and burdensome duties of the public service. Charles and his wife spent the evening here— The fifth century of experiments is an enquiry of plants or vegetables—of excellent and general use for food, medicine, and a number of mechanical arts— Acceleration of germination putting back or retardation of germination— Melioration of fruits, trees and plants. Compound fruits and flowers.— Sympathy and antipathy of plants; and making herbs and fruits medicinable, are the titles of the experiments, all in consort of this century. Many of them may be made useful; but many of them are experiments to be made; and I have neither the time, the materials nor the talent to make them. Some are given, with doubt or denial of the result; and the assignment of causes seldom is satisfactory.— Frequent reference is made to what he calls the spirits of plants trees and flowers, and heat and cold, and moist and dry, and harsh and soft are attributed to them as vital properties— I am puzzled with the multitude of specific names of fruits and flowers and plants which I never knew, or have totally forgotten. The same remarks are applicable to the musical instruments and technical musical terms of preceding centuries. The first remark on the Review of Lord Nugent’s Memorials of John Hampden is the fierce Republican Spirit in which it is written— The reverential and apologetic tone in behalf of the republican cause, and the bitterness of invectives against James and Charles and Laud, and Strafford, and the whole breed of the Stuarts.

The wound below my knee continues to fester and inflame The tendon of my right leg is yet sore and painful and a discolouring of extravasated blood appears below the outer ankle bone.— I was obliged to ride to and from meeting both morning and afternoon, and walking was more painful to me than it had yet been. On going to bed this evening I resolved to try the effect of a bread and milk poultice to the knee— Mr Waterston is ordained as a Minister at large, and officiates at the Pitts Street Chapel in Boston. He exchanged this day with Mr Lunt, and preached this morning from Matthew 24.12. “And because iniquity shall abound the love of many shall wax cold.”— Mr Waterston is a young man, warm hearted, and enthusiastic in the cause of evangelical religion and of his Country.— The text is part of the chapter in which Jesus shortly before his crucifixion prepared his disciples for the persecutions and sufferings which they were to endure for the preaching of the gospel— He foretold the destruction of the Temple of Jerusalem— He gives warning to the disciples that there shall be Wars and rumours of wars—that Nations shall rise up against Nation, and kingdom against kingdom.— That they the disciples shall be delivered up to be afflicted, and be killed, and be hated of all nations for his name’s sake—that many should be offended, and betray one another, and hate one another— And for all this he adds because iniquity shall abound, the love of many shall wax cold—but then he adds—he that shall endure unto the end, shall be saved— And this gospel of the kingdom shall be preached in all the world for a witness unto all Nations: and then shall the end come.— The prediction has been verified in all its parts except the coming of the end, which is not yet consummated. The gospel is not yet consummated— Even yet iniquity abounds, and the love of many waxes cold.— The sincere and righteous Christian suffers not his love to wax cold—he sees iniquity abound, and some betray, and some desert and some wax cold— The voice of the Saviour has told him that the end shall come, and what end shall be.— The Christian waits in fervent faith and humble hope, and all embracing Charity, for the universal emancipation of the race, ready to promote it to the utmost of his power: and knowing if it must be atchieved through blood and slaughter and exterminating War, it will be because the Supreme Ruler of the world shall have ordained that so it shall be.— After dinner Mr Waterstons text was Exodus 14.15. “And the Lord said unto Moses, wherefore criest thou unto me? Speak unto the children of Israel that they go forward.” A brief reference to the condition of the children of Israel, at the time when this injunction was laid upon them introduced a parallel between their undertaking and the burden upon the Soul of the Christian at this day—and he impressively exhorted his hearers, not only to be solicitous of sound opinions and virtuous principles, but to follow them up by going forward— President Quincy, and Mr Waterston spent the Evening with us. The Steamer Acadia arrived at 3 O’Clock this afternoon from Liverpool, with 109. Passengers, among whom was the Ex-Governor John Davis.

Sleepless Night— Heard Willard’s Clock in the entry successively strike 11. 12. 1. 2, 3. 4. Up twice in the Night and then rose wearied and disheartened for the occupations of the day— The fruit of the night was eight doggrel lines for the Album left here by Mr Beale of a young Lady which has been lying a fortnight upon my table— Mr Owen of Montgomery Alabama, and his wife a handsome Georgian, paid us an afternoon visit— He is a native of the State of Maine, and they are on their way to visit his father who lives at Wayne in that State— Mr Owen emigrated Southward 20 years ago, and has been 16. years settled in Alabama— Mrs Owen on parting requested an Autograph which I gave her. I rode over Milton Bridge to Dorchester with Mrs Charles Adams—the only excursion of the day.— Charles and Walter Hellen went into Boston this morning and did not return till 11. at Night. They attended a Meeting at the Tremont Temple of the Young Men’s whig Club, of which Charles is the President, and before whom a splendid speech was delivered by the Senator Rufus Choate— I read yesterday the sixth and this morning the seventh century of Bacon’s Sylva Sylvarum. They chiefly consist of experiments upon plants and trees—roots, leaves, flowers fruits, trunk and boughs, germination, growth and decay.— The experiments record many of the wonderful phenomena of vegetation— I ought to derive great store of knowledge from these experiments, many of which form part of the history of my seedling trees— But I have lost much of my memory, especially, relating to philosophical enquiry, and the multitude of experiments disables for the intimate remembrance of any.— I fasten only upon the passages where he explains his own systems; as in closing his enquiries concerning plants. Experiment 676. he says— [“]We leave the description of plants, and their virtues to herbalists, and other like books of natural history; wherein men’s diligence hath been great, even to curiosity; for our experiments are only such, as do ever ascend a degree to the deriving of causes, and extracting of axioms, which we are not ignorant, but that some both of the ancient and modern writers have also laboured; but their causes and axioms are so full of imagination, and so infected with the old received theories, as they are mere inquisitions of experience, and concoct it not.” Now as to his investigation of causes, he explains all the arcana of vegetation, by a movement of Spirits; which he attributes to all vegetable as well as to all animal nature—and the properties of all trees and plants are under the dominion of Spirits, not less than Men and women— But what are these Spirits of plants Towards the close of the 7th. century, he starts off upon experiments on yawning—on the hiccough—sneezing—tenderness of teeth, the tongue, the taste, pestilential seasons—simples for medicines—and Venus.

I slept this morning till near 4. O’Clock, and rose much refreshed. But my wife was much indisposed all this day and confined to her chamber till towards Evening. Mrs John Adams still keeps her bed, and though yesterday, and the day before apparently recovering was again this day not so well— My own lameness of the right leg, continues without abatement of the sprain and without healing of the wounded part.— The restriction of exercise makes time hang heavy upon my hands, and suspends almost entirely the proposed address to my Constituents— Charles, and Walter Hellen got back from Boston last Evening about 11. O’Clock— The whig club meeting was at the Tremont Temple— Charles presided and Mr Choate delivered a speech of splendid eloquence against the annexation of Texas. Henry Hardwick was here again about that acre, and three quarters of land back of his house, which he has set his heart upon purchasing of me— He now offers me at the rate of forty dollars an acre for it, which he says is much more than it is worth— I told him I would go and see the place and give him an answer; but that to sell it for forty dollars an Acre, or for five times that amount was out of the question. He said that it would then not be worth while for me to go and look at it.— The heat this day was oppressive and languid. The diary occupied me till dinner— After which I resorted to the couch for half an hour, but without repose— I then attempted to read Macaulay’s Review of Lord Mahon’s History of the War of the succession in Spain, but soon found I was reading to no purpose— Taking no interest in what I read—dragging heavily along from page to page and dosing over them all.— So I rode out in the Barouche with Louisa C. Smith and Mrs Charles Adams— She alighted to pay a visit to Mrs Lunt—we drove by the new road through Copeland street to Braintree, and returning over Penn’s hill took up again Mrs Charles and came home by Willard Street, and the Railway quarries. The ride was pleasant, but the afternoon was gone, and I had not written a line upon my task— And so passes day after day— I had read in the morning the 8th. Century of Bacon’s Sylva Sylvarum— These experiments are miscellaneous— Dr Rawley in his preface says that he who reads them attentively will find in them a secret order— But he says also that Lord Bacon himself said he had collected them without methodical order, to induce other men to do the same— This century begins with an experiment touching veins of medicinal earth— The next upon the growth of sponges—then upon sea-fish put in fresh waters— Drinks in Turkey— Sweat—and the glow-worm follow in succession. Where is the secret order between these? The experiments in consort touching the impressions, which the passions of the mind make upon the body are deeply interesting; but Caterpillars, Cantharides, Lassitude; is it not ludicrous to grope for a secret order of succession upon topics such as these?

The transition from Summer heat to autumnal cold took place with unusual force in the course of the last Night. It occurs simultaneously with the real close of the dog days—that is with the first morning appearance of Sirius, after his conjunction with the Sun. I have not been able to ascertain this to a day by observation for want of a succession of clear mornings at the time of the transition; but I have no doubt it is between the 15th. and 20th. of August. There had been prospects of rain and threats of thunder gust, with the intense heat of the last two days— Last evening there was a light shower without thunder, and in the night a heavy gale, which continued after I rose this morning, and finally cleared off with a crystal Northwester and bracing cold. The third night poultice upon my wounded knee, not even cooled the inflammation around it. Dr Woodward who after several days of intermission, from inflammation of his eyes, came again to visit my wife and Mrs John Adams, looked at my knee, and advised the application of lead water which was accordingly done— And after dinner I rode with Miss Smith, Mrs Charles, her boy Arthur and Mary-Louisa, round by the lower landing and over Penn’s hill.— I read the ninth century of the Sylva Sylvarum, and the close of Macaulay’s Review of Lord Mahon’s History of the War of the Spanish succession— The Experiments of the 9th century are various, and some of them mystical— The first one touching perception in bodies insensible, tending to natural divination or subtile trials— And he begins with a startling assertion, that all bodies whatever, though they have no sense, yet they have perception: for when one body is applied to another, there is a kind of election to embrace that which is agreeable, and to exclude or expel that which is ingrate— It is therefore a subject of a very noble inquiry, to inquire of the more subtile perceptions; for it is another key to open nature, as well as the sense; and sometimes better— And besides, it is a principal means of natural divination; for that which in these perceptions appeareth early, in the great effects cometh long after— That perception is an attribute of all bodies whatsoer, is a postulate which I am not prepared to grant; nor is it necessary for the argument which recommends the study of Secret Sympathies, and of which there is in nature multitudes sufficient for the curiosity of the most inquisitive spies of Nature— Bacon however is constantly repeating the principles of his system. “To apply, says he notions philosophical to plebeian terms; or to say, where the notions cannot fitly be reconciled that there wanteth a term or nomenclature for it, as the antients used, they be but shifts of ignorance; for knowledge will be ever a wandering and indigested thing, if it be but a commixture of a few notions that are at hand and occur and not excited from a sufficient number of instances, and those well collated” The chief interest of the Review of the History of the War of the Spanish succession is in the adventures and character of Mordaunt the eccentric Earl of Peterborough. For as to the two rival competitors for the crown of Spain the only question seems to be which was the most insignificant of the two.

Dr Woodward’s wash of lead water, promises to disperse the inflammation, and to heal the laceration of the skin below my knee; and although the tendon from the joint of the knee down to the sole of the foot is yet sore and the space between the outer ankle bone and the heel is almost black, I am getting daily an easier use of my limb. I answered a Letter, from Daniel P. King, declining his invitation to a political whig meeting at Lynn the 4th. of next Month— This afternoon there came as visitors, a Mr. Thayer, a son of my old acquaintance the late Solomon Thayer of Braintree, and with him, Mr and Mr Richardson, now Residents at St. Louis, Missouri, Mr and Mrs Bacon of Boston, with a daughter ten or twelve years old, and Mrs Jones, of whom I learnt only the name.— Charles and his wife went to Boston, taking their boy Arthur with them to consult Dr Bigelow, upon his case— But he thought Time and Patience would bring the remedy— Niles’s Register of the 17th. which came this day contains an Article of historical facts relative to the Florida Treaty of 1819. and a series of Articles under the head of Southern Convention, marking the movement of the Southern Disunionists to carry through the Texas annexation conspiracy.— Captain Tyler has at last issued an address to his friends withdrawing his name as a Candidate for election as President of the United States— They absorbed my attention and stimulated my industry, full three hours of this day— Shall it be in vain?— I read the tenth and last century of Bacon’s Sylva Sylvarum. He calls it a Natural History; but so is Hannah Glasse’s cookery book— There are one thousand experiments in consort or solitary of heterogeneous character, many of them exceedingly curious, but huddled together without commune vinculum to keep any thing upon the memory— The last century commences with experiments in concert touching the transmission and influx of immateriate virtues, and the force of imagination. This topic is inexhaustible— He says it is “such as we are a little doubtful to propound; it is so prodigious: but that it is so constantly avouched by many; and we have set it down as a law to ourselves to examine things to the bottom; and not to receive upon credit, or reject upon improbabilities, until there hath passed a due examination.”— 986— [“]I myself remember, that being in Paris, and my father dying in London, two or three days before my fathers death, I had a dream, which I told to divers English gentlemen; that my father’s house in the country was plaistered all over with black mortar.”— The last Experiment is solitary touching the general sympathy of men’s spirits— The delight which men have in popularity, fame, honour, submission, and subjection of other men’s minds, wills or affections, although these things may be desired for other ends, seemeth to be a thing in itself, without contemplation of consequence, grateful and agreeable to the nature of man &c. quod vide— Then I returned cursorily to Macaulay’s review of Lord Mahon’s history of the War of the Spanish succession—that War which made Europe an Aceldama for twelve years to settle whether Charles of Austria, or Philip of Anjou should be the Roi fainéant of Spain.

A gentle rain began last evening, and continued through the Night— This day was cloudy—chilling cold closing with thunder, lightening and a heavy shower, without clearing up.— I received yesterday a copy of J. Middleton’s Celestial Atlas with the small volume its companion—a present from the author in England. The work with which judge John Davis had made me acquainted last Summer, and of which I then expressed to him my approbation— Mr James Savage had on his last visit to England become acquainted with the author, and through his means a correspondence had been opened between Mr Middleton and judge Davis.— The judge communicated to Mr Middleton my favourable opinion of his work, and this present is forwarded to me by the hands of Mr Savage— This day I was by the condition of the weather confined almost entirely to the house, and towards Evening Mrs Treadway, with her Son in Law and daughter Mr and Mrs Crane, and their infant Son, came in from Richmond, Virginia, New-York and Boston— Charles and his wife passed the Evening with us— I read this morning, the New Atlantis of Lord Bacon— Like the Sylva Sylvarum, a posthumous publication, by Doctor William Rawley; said by him to be a work unfinished— It is in form, a fable somewhat like Swift’s Captain Gulliver, the narrative of an Island, discovered on a voyage from Peru, to China, and Japan— Rawley says it was devised to exhibit a model or description of a College instituted for the interpreting of nature, and the producing of great and marvellous works, for the benefit of men; under the name of Solomon’s house; or the College of the six days work— He says too that Bacon first intended to have included in this frame a code of laws, or of the best state or mould of a Commonwealth— But this was never performed; foreseeing it would be a long work, his desire of collecting the Natural history diverted him, which he preferred many degrees before it— The New Atlantis in regard to its near affinity with the Natural History is printed immediately after it— The Solomon’s house is a college for the collection of experiments in Natural History— A stone house for the ten centuries— The governor of the island tells the traveller that about 3000 years before, they had ships that “went sundry voyages, as well to your Straits, which you call the pillars of Hercules, as to other parts in the Atlantic and Mediterranean Seas; as to Peguin, which is the same with Cambaline, and Quinzy, upon the Oriental seas, as far as to the borders of the east Tartary.”— Where did he get that Quinzy?— I still read without yet finishing Macaulay’s review of Horace Walpole’s Letters to Sir Horace Mann— Macaulay cuts him up without mercy—but he is more exorable to the memory of his father; Sir Robert— Horace’s writings have amused me so much, and are so full of genius that I had not analyzed his character with such a steel pen as Macaulay’s. I wrote a page of task—but was obliged to set up till half past eleven to finish it— My subject spreads till I lose sight of its central point.

A dull, cold, cloudy day, without rain, most busily occupied, with no other efficient action than a walk before dinner; with Mr Crane up the hill of Charles’s house Charles himself was gone to Boston, but returned home to dine— We saw his wife, and Mr Crane admired the prospect of the harbour—the islands, the city, the village, and the western hills. My garden and Nursery rambles are barren and my meditations teeming but as yet unfruitful— I cannot do the writing and the reading of my daily task in one day—one of them is and must be sacrificed to the other I read this morning Mr Bacon in praise of knowledge, and began his Valerius Terminus or the Interpretation of Nature; with the Annotations of Hermes Stella— A few fragments of the first book— And then there is a Note, that none of the annotations of Stella are set down in these fragments— Of all this title there is no explanation— Valerius Terminus and Hermes Stella with annotations, not set down must explain themselves— I see nothing but fragments of the first book of an immense imaginary work upon the interpretation of Nature—extremely curious—but profoundly to be studied—22 quarto pages. I intended to have them for this mornings portion, but before I had got half through came the daily mail and newspapers; and in the Boston Courier of this Morning the address of John Tyler to his friends throughout the Union, withdrawing his name from the canvas, as a candidate for election of President— To this step he has been driven, by a deputation of Democrats from New York; disclosing to him that cannot get up an electoral ticket; to vote for him in any one State in the Union— His address is a Captain Bobadil brag of the prosperity of the Country all the merit of which he claims as due to his administration, and a viperous string of invective against Henry Clay, Chancellor Kent, Thomas H. Benton and me— The dirtiest of his spite is vented upon me. He is perhaps too low for further notice from me, but as the tool of others hate his address is not to be overlooked or despised— I have come in my own address to my constituents to the point of my own vindication, and the exposure of the base Jackson and Erving plot against me, which it will require all my energy and more than all my discretion to manage— A falser and fouler conspiracy never debased the character of man than this— To show it in all its turpitude to the world is my duty to the world and to my self— I have the power and the means—the transcendent difficulty is to do it with calmness and composure, and without an unbecoming manifestation of temper— Medio tutissimus ibis— Not the tameness of a nameless victim, not the tempest that loses self command. Oh! for a curb upon my temper!— I am still also labouring through, Macaulays characteristics of Horace Walpole, and his father— Charles and his wife, and Mr Beale spent the evening with us

Dr Frothingham preached this morning from Matthew 25.18. “But he that had received one went and digged in the earth, and hid his Lord’s money”— The Dr. observed that every part of this parable of the Talents was rich with instruction, and every word in which it is related, subject for grave and varied meditation— The commendation of the Servants to whom the lord had entrusted severally the 5 and the two talents was susceptible of improvements impressing the duties of diligence and fidelity; but it was worthy of enquiry what was the precise nature of the wickedness of him, who digged in the earth and hid his Lord’s money— It was not dishonesty, not selfish avarice, no embezzlement—no conversion of the money to his own use— It was not careless, extravagant, or foolish investment of the money, exposing it to be lost. He returned it to the Lord, as he had received it from him, without diminution without increase— But his duty was to improve the fund entrusted to his care— He was not the faithless, but the unprofitable servant. That was his wickedness, and for that his punishment was just as it was severe. His inaction had been caused by a sullen, discontented, disrespectful temper. The reason that he assigned for his neglect of duty was offensive to his Lord— He said he knew him to be a hard man, reaping where he had not sown, and gathering where he had not strewed— The very considerations which should have spur’d him on to the most active exertions to turn his talent to account— In the corresponding narrative by Luke of the same parable, 19.20. The servant says he had laid up the talent in a Napkin— There is indeed so much in the narrative between the two Evangelists that it might reasonably be questioned whether they are one and the same story. Dr Frothingham’s discourse was copious in thought, and forcible in application— He walked home with me, and dined with us. We rode to meeting in the afternoon in a flood rather than a shower of rain— The auditory was very small—about 40 persons, of whom perhaps ten women— The afternoon discourse was from 2. Corinthians 12.7. “And lest I should be exalted above measure, through the abundance of the revelations, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, the messenger of Satan to buffet me, lest I should be exalted above measure.” The words underscored were the text, and there was no comment on the repetition of the assignment of the purpose for which this mysterious and unexplained thorn in the flesh was given— The Doctor’s eldest son Thomas came out with him, and with Walter Hellen dined with Mrs Charles on the hill, while Charles himself dined with us. The Doctor returned to Boston, and Charles and his wife spent the evening with us.

I have so far recovered from my lameness that I was able this morning to give one hour before and after sunrise to exercise, and piddling with my seedling trees. I saw the Sunrise, and filled an earthen pot to sow in it apple and pear-seeds— I mixed manure with earth from the richest mould of the garden for my experiments— But this time lost me the day for my task— Mr Waterston the father of the clergyman; and a young congregational minister, a native of this State, settled at Louisville, Kentucky called and spent about two hours with me in conversation— Mr Hayward on leaving me requested an autograph, for Miss Eliza Speed, a young Lady of Louisville, which I gave him— My Son brought me a Letter from Mr John G. Palfrey with a subscription paper to make up an annuity of 1500 dollars for the benefit of Miss Harriet Welsh. Upon consultation with Charles, I determined to leave the alternative to Mr Palfrey, of adding my subscription to the fund, or of continuing a separate and larger provision from year to year.— We spoke also of my design to build in connection with his house on the hill a fire proof granite edifice for the safe keeping of my library, and of my father’s and my own manuscript books and papers— Mr Crane and Walter Hellen, went this afternoon to Boston for an excursion to Lowell to-morrow— I have finished reading the fragments of Bacon upon the interpretation of Nature.— A Summary abridgement of a great work never finished— Full of instruction; not well digested an enormous mass of gold in the mine.— Here the 16th. chapter is indicative of the celebrated four idols—thus— [“]Of the inherent and profound errors and superstitions in the nature of the mind, and of the four sorts of idols or false appearances that offer themselves to the understanding in the inquisition of knowledge; that is to say, the idols of the tribe, the idols of the palace, the idols of the cave, and the idols of the theatre.— That these four added to the incapacity of the mind, and the vanity and malignity of the affections, leave nothing but impotency and confusion.— A recital of the particular kinds of these four idols, with some chosen examples of the opinions they have begot, such of them as have supplanted the state of knowledge most.”— At the close of the book are two profound observations.— 1. “Of the singular advantage which the Christian religion hath towards the furtherance of true knowledge in that it excludeth and interdicteth human reason, whether by interpretation or anticipation, from examining or discussing of the mysteries and principles of faith.” 2. “That monarchies incline wits to profit and pleasure: and Commonwealths to glory and vanity. That universities incline wits to sophistry and affectation; cloisters to fables and unprofitable subtilty; study at large to variety; and that it is hard to say, whether mixture of contemplations with an active life, or retiring wholly to contemplations, do disable and hinder the mind more.”— Not a word read of Macaulay. Not a line written of the task

No sight of morning stars, or of rising or setting Sun.— My Son went to Boston, and returned to dine Mr Withington is a young student of divinity recently from the theological school at Cambridge— A native of Dorchester and now residing there— He assigned two motives for his call to see me—one, as a manifestation of personal respect for my character— The other to ask my opinions upon some scruples which troubled him with regard to his voting at the presidential election— He was an abolitionist in principle, though not of the abolition party; nor of any abolition Society. He was also a whig and strongly desirous of voting for the whig candidate— But the Liberty party charged him with being an avowed duelist—and not only a Slave holder, but a decided partizan for perpetual Slavery— A gambler—intemperate, and otherwise of loose licentious life— There was no satisfactory refutation of these charges made public, and he was much perplexed what to do. He needed advice and came to ask it of me— I said that his doubts were of no easy solution. That I took no part as a partizan in the presidential election I deemed it my duty to abstain from canvassing for any one for that office, and to leave it to the people to fix their choice for themselves.— But as to matters of fact I would say what I knew or believed and as to principles, what I think— Mr Clay is a Slave holder and a supporter of Slavery— I believe him in error upon those points; and hope he will revise and reform his opinions. He is a man of the world—of self-indulgent habits; but not as I believe a gambler or intemperate— He abhors dueling, and has been engaged in several duels— A rigorous puritanical principle of morals cannot be applied to the exercise of the right of suffrage— There must be some reference to the result— Mr Clay’s chief competitor is vastly more exceptionable than he— To vote for a third candidate who cannot be elected is in effect to vote for the worst of the three— Mr Withington thanked me. My reasoning evidently failed to convince him— Mr Crane and Walter Hellen returned from their excursion to Lowell, and we took tea, and spent the Evening at Charles’s house— Except my wife who is much indisposed— Mary, who is yet confined to her chamber, and Walter Hellen, who came from Lowell with a cold and head ache.— I read of Bacon the Filum Labyrinthi, sive formula inquisitionis ad Filios— Pars Prima—but there is no second part. It begins— Francis Bacon thought in this manner— Loose thoughts— Objections to the prevailing systems and modes of teaching— Next to these Sequela chartarum sive Inquisitio Legitima de Calore et frigore— Sectio Ordinis. Charta suggestionis, sive memoria fixa.— Experiments upon heat and cold— Then follow Physiological remains— Inquisitions touching the compounding of metals. These are short separate tracts, the Latin titles of which are fantastical and unintelligible— Small issues of gigantic projects.

My Son went with Mr Crane went to Cambridge and attended the Commencement— I had very urgent invitations to attend the three days, yesterday at the meeting of the alumni, when judge White of Salem delivered an Oration two hours long— This day, being Commencement—and to-morrow—the day for the Boylston prize declamations, and for the Φ.B.K. (Phi Beta Kappa) Society meeting. Oration by Revd George Putnam and Poem— On full deliberation and special consideration of my lameness I concluded not to go, on either of the days.— I had special invitations this day from Dr John Codman of Dorchester and Dr George Parkman of Boston to the rooms of their Sons, who were graduated this day. Dr Francis Parkman of Boston, and Mr Leverett Saltonstall of Salem have also sons graduates of this day.— Charles and Mr Crane returned this afternoon before sunset— Harvey Field came this afternoon, and after much chaffering agreed to give 3000 dollars for the Quincy meadow, 6 Acres of the Penn’s valley farm— He proposed also to sell to me his own house and farm, and also to clear out the brook behind the native spot houses; concerning all which I propose to take further advice— Mr Davis an Architect was here this evening with plans for an enlargement of Charles’s house, and for appending to it a fire proof building for the preservation and safe keeping of my father’s and my own manuscript books and papers— I have long been deeply anxious upon this subject— The library and the manuscripts are all now in houses liable every day of the year and every hour of the day to be consumed by fire. My career must very shortly close; and I look with intense feeling to posterity for the preservation of my father’s name, and of my own as his son. All my hopes are centered in my surving son and his infant children—daughters may possibly transmit inheritances, but not names— My son will not dishonour his, but how frail and precarious is the tenure of a single life! what a lottery the chances of virtue, wisdom and prosperity even of one among four small children! I feel the necessity of guarding against casualties from external causes, from the decays of nature and accidents of fire. For the rest in humble reverence and hope I rely upon mercy from on high— I read this morning, Articles of Questions touching Minerals— The Lord Bacon’s questions with Dr Meverel’s solutions— Then the Lord Verulams Inquisition concerning the versions, transmutations multiplications and effections of bodies— After which, a Speech touching the recovering of drowned mineral works— Certain experiments about weight in air and water— Sudden thoughts under the title of Experiments for Profit—and experiments upon simple and compound liquors—and about attractive and repulsive bodies— My task languishes in the search for documents of the 15th. Congress 2d. Session.

My Granddaughter Louisa-Catherine, brought me an Album of a Miss Eleanor B. Fearing of New-York, now a visitor at Mr Lunt’s, with a request that I would put some thing in it; and it must be done immediately, for the young Lady was going for New-York this afternoon. I could not mortify my granddaughter by a refusal and wrote a short Stanza. I keep copies of all these Album Fadaises; but am ashamed to meet four out of five of them— These offscourings of the wits of distinguished persons are almost universally dull. But it is better to be dull than churlish.— Of Lord Bacon the physiological remains which I read yesterday are followed by the medical remains—a sort of apothicary’s shop; a catalogue of astringents, openers and cordials instrumental to health— An extract for his own use out of the book of the prolongation of life; and recipes of his own— 32 empirical nostrums of pills, potions, clysters and quackeries Among which 14. Never to keep the body in the same posture above half an hour at a time 15 Four precepts. To break off custom. To shake off spirits ill disposed. To meditate on youth. To do nothing against a man’s genius. 26. Heroic desires— 28 To provide always an apt breakfast.— The series closes with medical receipts for the gout and the stone— And then come the Works Moral— Beginning with a fragment of the Colours of Good and Evil. To the Lord Mountjoye— In the dedication he says, he takes his subject from the last part of the best book of Aristotle, who he says does not deliver, and unwrap himself well of that he seemeth to conceive; nor to be a master of his own knowledge— There are ten colours, or appearances of Good and Evil— Extracts from Aristotle—but given in Latin; and of which he presents his analysis of persuasives and dissuasives—detecting the fallacies of the Stagirite— For my task I had a long search for documents of the second Session of the 15th. Congress of which I have two sets and could find neither of them complete, and miss especially the report of the select Committee of the House of Representatives on General Jackson’s Seminole War Campaign. In searching however for these, I found some others which I wanted, but did not know where to look for them— As Niles’s Register for 1819 and Onis’s pamphlet in a volume of the Casket.— The casual and unforeseen interruptions to my labours are teazing and many. This evening I was taken away, to go and take tea with our Ladies, at Mrs T. B. Adams’s. My wife can go nowhere and Mrs John Adams is still confined to her chamber— Mrs Foster and Elizabeth C. Adams have just returned from their excursion to Quebec and the Falls. Mr and Mrs G. T. Bigelow and Charles Miller were at Mrs T. B. Adams’s.

The moon was full last Tuesday, and shone this morning when I rose almost as bright as day. The whole Constellation of Orion the great and little dog-stars, Venus, and the twins were all brilliant before my windows— Sirius about 10 minutes and Venus about 20— I saw the Sun rise from the East corner of Charles’s house.— I went to Boston and attended the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society. Mrs Treadway went with me, and alighted at her friend Mrs Boardman’s, in Hancock street— I called at the Emancipator and Morning Chronicle Office, and saw Mr Leavitt, Mr Phelps and Milton Clarke, a fugitive white Slave, very like Tibbatts, came in while I was there. We spoke of the case of Charles T. Torrey at Baltimore. The Habeas Corpus is to be tried before chief Justice Taney next Wednesday 4. September. I told Mr Leavitt that Mr. M. M. Fisher of Medway had written me a Letter requesting an interview with me for a Committee of the Liberty party of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts with reference to the nomination of a Candidate to represent the District in the 29th. Congress— He named the 12th of this Month as the day when they wished to call on me if convenient; and he requested me to name the hour of that or any other day when it would be agreeable to me to receive them. I answered the Letter, assuring him that I would with pleasure receive the Committee, on the day named by him between 10 and 12 O’Clock, or on either of the two immediately succeeding days, at their convenience. But they did not come on either of the days, nor have I heard from them or from Mr Fisher since— I was apprehensive that he might not have received my Letter. Mr Leavitt said he believed it was so, and that he would give Mr Fisher notice of the fact— I desired him to add that I shall be glad to see the Committee upon any day that may suit them— Walking in the Street I met the Revd. George Putnam, who yesterday delivered the Phi Beta Kappa Oration at Cambridge. I told him I proposed to call at his house, and ask leave to examine the old parish Register of his Church for the names of Boylston and White— At the meeting of the historical Society— I presented copies of my Oration at Cincinnati, and of my Lecture at Braintree upon Education. Mr George Bancroft delivered an argument to prove that Samuel Adams was the author of a petition to the king in 1768— J. G. Palfrey was chosen by ballot to deliver on theof October next a semi-centurial Oration on the history and progress of the Society— I lent to Joseph Willard, the copy of the old Braintree town Register. Robert C. Winthrop was there, and said he had received a Letter from George W. Erving, about his statements to President Jackson, a Letter to be seen by no eyes but his; but extracts of which he would send me I called at Mr James H Foster’s and saw Mrs Foster Louisa and Mary. Returned with Mrs Treadway to Quincy to dine— Evening visitors.
Sun rose 5.23. Set 6.37. Over Pray’s Elm.

While I was gone to Boston yesterday Mr Harrison Gray Otis came out to pay me a visit with his Son in Law, Andrew Ritchie— And last evening two young Ladies, Miss Bartlett and Miss Wood invited me to a Pic-Nic where the Ladies of Quincy are to meet in a grove behind Mrs T. B. Adams’s house, next Thursday at 3. O’Clock P.M. and said the Ladies would be glad if I would speak to them— I said if my health would permit I would come, and if the spirit should move would speak a few words— Our late evening visitors, were Elizabeth C. Adams, Mrs George T. Bigelow, and Charles Miller— This morning I gave again the two morning hours till Sunrise to exercise and work sub Jove— My son and Walter Hellen started upon a week’s excursion to Wood’s hole, and perhaps to Nantucket. Mr Crane was to have gone with them, but on his tour to Lowell took a fit of Asthma, which became so severe that last Night leeches were applied to his breast, and he was this day confined to the house.— I had no visitors, and excepting the time consumed by the Siesta, now become a necessary of life, and the time lost in the search and consultation of documents I was able to write rather more than my daily page. But my progress is Snail paced— I have come in the reading of Bacon, to the Essays—Civil and Moral, which having read more than once, I shall now pass over. There are three dedications of this book. 1. to his brother Anthony Bacon 30 January 1597. 2. To his loving brother Sir John Constable Kt. and 1612. 3. to Villiers, duke of Buckingham, the worthless favourite of James and Charles. 1625— The last signed Fran. St. Alban— It was the last year of his life He died 9 April 1626. In the second dedication he says the former edition had been often printed—and in the third he says that of all his other works his Essays have been most current— They have been so ever since— Numberless editions of them have been published— So that it is no vain boasting when he says, I do conceive, that the Latin volume of them, being in the universal language, may last as long as books last. But I suppose that in these days, the English original finds many more readers than the Latin translation— The Essays are followed by a Collection of Apophthegms, New and old 150 of which I read this day. In his preface to them he refers to the example of Julius Caesar, and says its pity that book is lost— If they are not better than Bacon’s they are no great loss.— He says they are mu crones verborum pointed speeches. He says he will not omit any because they are vulgar; for many vulgar ones are excellent good—that may be—but some of his are beastly filthy, and ought never to have been published— The practice of collecting apophthegms is perhaps good, but these are upon the whole flat and unprofitable.
